summary: This is an email chain between a US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) prosecutor and an unidentified sender, discussing setting up an automatic email forwarding rule for court document 'bounces' related to Ghislaine Maxwell, similar to one previously set up for Jeffrey Epstein after his indictment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the email discussion about receiving court document notifications ('bounces'); referenced in a linked news article about sobbing during her court appearance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the previous subject for whom an automatic email forwarding rule for court bounces was set up after his indictment.

connections.description: Maxwell is discussed in the context of a procedural rule previously established for Epstein, indicating their legal cases are connected in the eyes of the prosecutors.

events.title: Maxwell sobs in court
events.description: Referenced via a New York Post article link stating Ghislaine Maxwell sobbed during her court appearance.

events.title: Indictment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Mentioned as the past event that triggered the initial setup of an automatic email forwarding rule for court bounces.

keyFacts: Prosecutors from the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) were coordinating to receive automatic email notifications ('bounces') for court documents related to Ghislaine Maxwell's case.
A similar automatic forwarding system had been previously established for Jeffrey Epstein's case after his indictment.
The correspondence references a New York Post article from July 5, 2020, reporting that Ghislaine Maxwell sobbed during a court appearance.
The email chain demonstrates ongoing procedural coordination between a prosecutor and another party (likely a colleague or paralegal) regarding case monitoring.
